title: Refresh of the copyright literacy strategy
content: To mark the start of 2026 Chris and I had a day of planning for the year. We often used to do a annual review at the end of each year to list out the publications we had written, the conferences we had spoken at and the research we had been involved in This year we started out by reviewing the Copyright Literacy Strategy that we put together in 2020. Although we never formally published this document, we did refer to it over the last few years to help maintain direction and moment. We realised d
creator: Jane Secker
sourceDescription: Decoding copyright and bringing you enlightenment

title: Webinar 83 – Return of the copyright trolls
content: The copyright trolls are back in town! Image from JNL, FAL, via Wikimedia Commons In our latest webinar, Tim Riley (Aberdeen) and Liesl Rowe (Leeds Beckett University) will discuss the issue of copyright trolling: what it is; how best to prevent it; and strategies for dealing with it, all with reference to case studies from their own institutions. This webinar is a return to the topic, which was discussed in Webinar 39 when we explored the practice of some photographers using agencies to aggress
creator: Kathryn D
sourceDescription: Decoding copyright and bringing you enlightenment

title: Webinar 82: Big Fat Copyright Quiz 2025
content: “Oh COOLSIG Quiz, Oh Coolsig quiz, How baffling are your questions….” The last COOLSIG webinar of 2025 is on Friday, December 19th at 11:00am . And as it Christmas, that can mean only one thing – it’s time for the now traditional Big Fat Copyright Quiz Of The Year ! Santa and his helpful elf will be welcoming COOLSIG’s resident question mistress, Kathryn, as she attempts to put together a selection of questions on the events of 2025, copyright and any other ra
creator: Kathryn D
sourceDescription: Decoding copyright and bringing you enlightenment

title: Webinar 81: Highights of Icepops 2025
content: This coming Friday, 14th November is a chance to catch up with 5 speakers from September’s Icepops conference , which took place at the John Rylands Library at the University of Manchester. We have 4 guests joining us live and one delivering a recorded presentation. This is your chance to hear: Doug McCarthy – ‘The Sunflower is Mine’ – Paradoxical Patterns in the Public Domain. Ana Enriquez – Community and Joy through Learning: CopyrightX: Libraries. Megan Kilvington – Na
creator: Jane Secker
sourceDescription: Decoding copyright and bringing you enlightenment

title: Copyright waffling with Rt. Hon. Professor Sir Robin Jacob
content: We are delighted to announce the launch of a brand new episode of the Copyright Waffle podcast, recorded at UCL School of Laws in January 2025. We were honoured to be joined by the Rt. Hon. Professor Sir Robin Jacob who was possibly our most distinguished guest on the podcast to date! It was our first time interviewing a Judge and what a fascinating insight it was into the world of IP case law. Professor Jacob is a former High Court and Court of Appeal of England and Wales Judge. As a barrister
creator: Jane Secker
sourceDescription: Decoding copyright and bringing you enlightenment

title: Webinar 80: Coventry’s bold leap into Open Educational Resources
content: In our first webinar of the new academic year, we will be inviting you to join us for a transformative session on how Coventry University is reshaping access to learning through Open Educational Resources (OER). In “The Great Escape: Coventry’s OER Leap of Faith” , Erica Levi and colleagues will share the story of how the Learning Resources Team responded to budget cuts not with compromise, but with innovation. Discover how they pivoted from costly commercial textbooks to a sustainable, student-
creator: Kathryn D
sourceDescription: Decoding copyright and bringing you enlightenment

title: Copyright anxiety in higher education: findings from our research
content: We are delighted to report that our latest research, co-authored with Amanda Wakaruk from the University of Alberta, into copyright anxiety was published earlier this week in the Journal of Copyright in Education and Librarianship . It’s a study of professionals in higher education, comparing Canada and the UK, but also drawing on the 2021 study that surveyed the general public in Canada and the USA. In our recent research we surveyed over 500 people and conducted seven focus groups to und
creator: Jane Secker
sourceDescription: Decoding copyright and bringing you enlightenment

title: Icepops bursary winners
content: We are delighted to announce the winners of the bursaries to attend Icepops 2025 at the University of Manchester next month. We are really grateful to the Copyright Licensing Agency for sponsoring the conference and allowing us to offer fully funded places to the five lucky recipients. Their sponsorship also means we have been able to keep the price low for all delegates, while offering a fabulous programme along with lunch, afternoon tea and an evening social. Sarah Brear, Development Manager:
creator: Jane Secker
sourceDescription: Decoding copyright and bringing you enlightenment

title: Library Associations and Copyright: A Global Snapshot of Engagement and Opportunity
content: Readers of this blog don’t need to be told that copyright is a cornerstone of library practice—shaping what we can do with the materials we acquire, whether through purchase or licence. Yet, despite its importance, copyright often takes a back seat in libraries to more visible concerns like funding or staffing. A new report from the International Federation of Library Associations and Institutions (IFLA), Library Associations and Copyright, aims to change that by offering a global overview
creator: Jane Secker
sourceDescription: Decoding copyright and bringing you enlightenment

title: Copyright Waffle with Icepops keynote Monica Westin
content: Monica, Jane and Chris in front of the Old Bodleian Library We are very excited to announce that we have a new episode of our podcast Copyright Waffle , this time with Icepops 2025 keynote Monica Westin. Monica is about to start a new role as Director of Open Policy Development at Cambridge University Press and Assessment. Her previous roles involved work at the California Digital Library, Google, the Internet Archive and Manchester Metropolitan University. As a result Monica has had a ringside
creator: cbowiemorrison
